title: 109_s49
content:
The Alaska Floodplain and Erosion Mitigation Commission Act of 2005 establishes a joint federal-state commission for floodplain and erosion mitigation in Alaska. It includes sections on the establishment of the commission, duties, administration, personnel matters, reports, termination, evaluation, prioritization, control, mitigation, and authorization of appropriations. The Alaska Floodplain and Erosion Mitigation Commission Act of 2005 establishes a joint federal-state commission for floodplain and erosion mitigation in Alaska. It defines key terms such as Commission, Alaska Native, Alaska Native village, Secretary, and State. The "Joint Federal-State Floodplain and Erosion Mitigation Commission for Alaska" is established with 7 members, including the Governor of the State as Cochairperson, members appointed by the Governor representing city or borough governments, an employee of the Department of the Interior appointed by the Secretary as Cochairperson, and another member appointed by the Secretary. The Commission, established with 7 members, includes appointees from various government departments. Members serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority, and vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission, with 7 members appointed from various government departments, retains its powers despite vacancies. Appointments must be made within 90 days. The Commission's initial meeting must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by Cochairpersons, with a majority constituting a quorum. Decisions require the concurrence of Cochairpersons, and the principal office is in Alaska. SEC. 102. DUTIES. The Commission established by this Act must meet at least twice a year for the first 2 years. They are required to conduct a study on flooding and erosion assistance alternatives and develop a policy for infrastructure investments in Alaska Native villages most affected by these issues. The Commission established by this Act must meet at least twice a year for the first 2 years to make recommendations on specific flood and erosion circumstances affecting life and property in the State, land use regulations, uses of flood- and erosion-prone land, and regulation of land designated for Alaska Native people. The Act establishes a Commission to address flood and erosion issues in Alaska, including land owned by Alaska Native corporations, government, city and borough, and private land. Procedures are set for public input on land use planning needs, such as flood and erosion control measures and data collection. The Commission established by the Act will evaluate flood and erosion circumstances affecting life and property in Alaska, develop recommendations for flood and erosion control solutions, review programs and budgets of Federal and State agencies, and suggest changes in laws and policies. The Commission will evaluate flood and erosion issues in Alaska, recommend solutions, review government programs and budgets, and propose changes in laws and policies for integrated Federal-State erosion and flood management authority, improved coordination between governments, avoiding conflicts with Alaska Native people, prioritizing long-term sustainability over short-term needs, and ensuring economic and social well-being. The Commission aims to prevent erosion and floods in Alaska to protect the economic and social well-being of Alaska Native people and residents through long-term planning. SEC. 103. ADMINISTRATION. The Commission shall establish a committee of technical advisers with expertise in coastal engineering, flood and erosion management, rural community planning, city and borough governments, State and local government relationships, and Alaska Native villages. The Commission must maintain complete records of its activities for public inspection and may hold hearings. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and accept gifts to carry out its duties. SEC. 104. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their employment status. Non-federal employees receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while federal or state employees serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses for Commission members are also allowed. The Commission members are allowed travel expenses and per diem for subsistence while performing duties away from their home or regular place of business. The Cochairpersons can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws, with the executive director's employment subject to confirmation by the Commission. Compensation for the executive director is determined by the Commission. The Cochairpersons of the Commission have the authority to set the compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain federal pay regulations. The maximum pay rate for these positions is capped at the level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Cochairpersons of the Commission have the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff at a maximum rate of level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without loss of civil service status or privilege. The Commission may also procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 105. REPORTS.

The Commission is required to submit interim reports annually by September 30, detailing its activities and any immediate needs or threats for coordinated responses to erosion and flooding emergencies. A final report is due by September 30, 2011, outlining the Commission's activities, findings, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. The Commission will terminate on September 30, 2011. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, will evaluate and prioritize flood and erosion circumstances affecting life and property in the State. Flood and erosion control and mitigation measures will be implemented. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, will examine cost-effective flood and erosion control solutions for 9 villages in the State. This includes using technology like moving structures, nonstructural land management, and structural erosion control techniques. Grants may be given to State and local governments for implementation. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, will consider factors like design life and cost effectiveness when implementing flood and erosion control solutions. The Federal share of project costs will be 75 percent. SEC. 203. MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, may take action to mitigate flood and erosion damage through relocation, elevation, flood proofing, and land management alternatives. SEC. 204. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary consults with the Commission and relevant agencies, oversees agencies developing relocation and flood mitigation plans, and maintains existing rights under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The Secretary retains authority to make contracts and grants. TITLE III--AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 301. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 301. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds are authorized for fiscal years 2006 through 2011 to carry out the Act, with $250,000 allocated for Commission expenses.
